In my clinical experience, most people struggle because their main motivations in life are to:

1) Feel good (addiction)
2) Avoid pain (avoidance)
3) Be right (ego)

Rather, I help people:
1) Be present (mindfulness) 
2) Open up (willingness)
3) Do what matters (be effective)

What are the drop-offs at each step of the funnel?

This is why tools that short-circuit parts of the funnel are hugely important – like @sendwyre

1105859214013014017.text:
• Deposit the tokens into your wallet

• After all this, the user lands in the product which likely requires new multi-step behavior involving money

1105859127279005699.text:
• Setup a user profile on the dapp (email, username, etc)

• Buy ETH (a complicated sub-funnel which takes multiple days: KYC/AML, wiring in money to an exchange)

• (maybe) transfer ETH to another exchange to buy the token required by the dapp e.g. DAI.

1105859056927940608.text:
• Land on the dapp website, and find the value-prop compelling enough to continue.

• Install and setup a wallet (a complicated sub-funnel involving new concepts, e.g. seed phrases)

• Login to the dapp with your wallet (requires new behavior i.e. signing messages)

1104087012087222272.text: Have you found any tactics to weave mindfulness into your day? Are there any products that facilitate this? Seems like a worthwhile area to explore

1104086976876036096.text: This seems effective but has all the difficulties of developing a new habit –– how do you remember to do it through the day?

1104086890892816384.text: So how we weave mindfulness into our day? The best approaches I’ve seen involve using structure – anchoring a “moment of mindfulness” to a specific activity. E.g. taking 1 minute before each meeting to meditate, or doing a bodyscan before you drink water

1104086844117925888.text: In the west, we are lay people (i.e. non-monks) who are *also* trying to meditate. And this is doubly difficult in our fast-paced world of smartphones, notifications, and multi tasking

1104086820235571200.text: Monks devote their days to meditation and so naturally have mindfulness extend into their day to day activities. Lay people support the monastics via donations but are not themselves trying to walk the path, for the most part

1104086773221666816.text: This may be because has been a historical separation between monastics and lay people in Asia, where the techniques come from

1104086732138377216.text: Seems like there is good material and guidance on meditation techniques and retreats (i.e. point 1) – but not  on how to integrate the practice into day to day life (i.e. point 2)

1104086705521348608.text: 2 is hard. It means you remain present instead of being default lost in though and moving on auto-pilot; observe emotions instead of getting wrapped up in them

1104086661774753792.text:
Feel like there are two pieces to meditation practice:

1- exploring the nature of your awareness (during a sit).

2- weaving mindfulness into your life (during the day).

(thread)

If someone wants to sit the game out (and not risk losing $200), they pay their fair share (200/n) to the 2nd-last card owner. 

I.e. if you’re the 2nd last card, you win money. If you’re the last card, you lose big time.

1006693848242900993.text: 20) Then there’s a granular description of the protocol: e.g. setting up the counterfactual structure for deposits; installing a new application in a state channel; making an instant withdrawal

1006693800452984833.text:
19) Towards the end, there’s a walk-through of smart contract architecture:
e.g. using delegatecall to allow for first looking up the address of a counterfactual object in the registry, and then calling the required function.

1006693725018484736.text:
18) Other points:
• State channels can interact with on-chain state.
• The Metachannel design allows interaction across intermediaries.

1006693659448958977.text:
17) Requirements for nodes:
• Participants need to store a bunch of stuff: their keys, records of their own actions, signed messages from others.
• Participants need to regularly check the blockchain.

Services that need to be built: hubs; watch towers; insurance providers.

1006693632676712448.text:
16) Limitations of state channels:
• The participant set must be known ahead of time.

1006693609792524289.text:
15) The object-oriented approach for counterfactual objects results in:
• Composability: can create larger counterfactual objects from pieces.
• Re-use of onchain design techniques (e.g. proxy contracts)
• Merkleized disputes: only challenge object one disagrees with.

1006693531455578118.text: 14) Can setup conditional finalization between contracts; making them finalize transitively.

1006693459447738368.text:
13) This involves:
• Counterfactual state
• Counterfactual instantiation
• Counterfactual addressing: via the global registry.
• Counterfactual objects: code + storage + id (which makes them unique).

1006693427331952640.text:
12) Counterfactual X is defined as:

1-  X could happen on-chain, but doesn’t
2- The enforcement mechanism allows any participant to unilaterally make X hap- pen
3- Participants can act as though X has happened

1006693379114242048.text: 11) Game-theoretic reasoning around Nash equilibrium helps specify certain parts of the protocol  – e.g. in the "Initiator-pays-fees" protocol: the initiator of a dispute pays for the fees.

1006693308259799042.text:
10) Clever strategies for mitigating unavailability griefing:
• Have a trusted third-party as a witness
• Commit to respond in a certain way (e.g. mutually assured destruction)
• pooling data availability as to increase cost to the griefer
• ..

1006693280602624000.text:
9) Onto griefing: the ability of a participant, with some cost and without directly benefiting, to harm another participant.

Why it exists: because unavailability is not a uniquely attributable fault.

1006693238718201857.text: 8) and one of the best discussions of threat models I’ve seen – defined as "the extent to which a state channel interaction is trustless, since actions outside of the threat model are trusted not to occur.”

1006693192371179520.text: 7) The paper has a good discussion of requirements (safety, finality, etc) & desired properties (minimized onchain operations; support high throughput; etc) ..

1006693022246031360.text:
6) In the counterfactual design, the installation, opening, and closing of new application will not require any on-chain transactions.

This allows channelization to be used by default.

1006692971239133189.text:
5) The team's viewpoint: blockchain users will not use most apps with high enough throughput to justify independent app-specific state channels.

So: need a framework that allows setup to happen once, and then allows all applications to use the existing channel.

1006692860639444992.text: 4) State channels proceed by “total consent” – any state change within the channel requires cryptographic consent from all parties.

1006692819451482113.text:
3) Sidechains do; if the sidechain blockchain consensus mechanism fails, that state may be lost forever.
Plasma & state channels don't: users can always restore their state to original blockchain.

Hat-tip to @technocrypto for making this point at EthDenver. :)

17) Check it out and let us know if you have any feedback.

Thanks to @mrsmkl , @ethchris , and others for massive contributions to the Truebit VM!

1000383275989393408.text:
16) The JIT is fast. (Shout-out to @Sunfishcode and Cretonne).
The interpreter is slow(er), but is only ever used in case of disputes.

1000383209039892480.text:
15) Truebit tasks execute efficiently because:

• the original run by Solver/Verifier uses a JIT, without the need for snapshots.
• the follow-up runs during verification games use the interpreter, with state snapshots.

1000383165788311552.text:
14) We have the following short & long-term avenues for data availability:
• store data on the blockchain –– contract storage, logs, or contract code.
• Jason Teutsch decentralized oracles: http://people.cs.uchicago.edu/~teutsch/papers/decentralized_oracles.pdf …
• Ethereum sharding – consensus on data.
• Filecoin and Swarm

1000383012146679808.text:
13) Truebit tasks can read inputs directly (as in the interactive Scrypt verification for the Doge-Ethereum bridge).

They can also read inputs from a decentralized filesystem (e.g. IPFS).

1000382957889163264.text: 12) The Truebit WebAssembly interpreter (written in Solidity) runs only *one phase* on chain.https://github.com/TrueBitFoundation/webasm-solidity …

1000382915660959745.text:
11) But.. disputed instructions are not actually run fully onchain.

Instead, the Truebit VM breaks each instructions into multiple *phases*.

E.g. i32.add has phases for popping the first stack item, the second stack item, summing them, and pushing the result onto the stack

1000382826989092865.text: 10) Disputes in step 2 or 3 also result in a verification game! Metering, pre-processing, and instantiation are implemented as deterministic WASM modules.

1000382772647784448.text:
9) Disputes in step 4 result in a Truebit verification game.

The challenger forces a binary search arriving at the first disputed step in O(log(n)) time, with n being the number of instructions

1000382713520705537.text:
8) Solver runs the task locally:

Step 1) download program and inputs from decentralized filesystem
Step 2) inject metering instructions into the code
Step 3) perform pre-processing & instantiate the VM
Step 4) run the code
Step 5) submit solution to the contract

1000382657145004032.text:
7) TaskGiver creates a task by declaring: 
• the program (a WebAssembly module), 
• the inputs 

And attaching some reward
• gas price
• gas limit

1000382565730148352.text:
6) The offchain interpreter can create state snapshots ––

A merkle tree including every part of the VM:
• the code
• the stack
• the linear memory
• the globals
• the calltable
• pc, stack_ptr, call_ptr
• …

1000382531039055872.text:
5) Instructions and memory are metered ––

Metering instructions are injected per block of code.

The VM keeps track of gas used in a counter, and terminates if the value exceeds the gasLimit.

1000382471140147200.text:
4) Tasks are priced using a similar mechanism to Ethereum:

The Task Giver sets a gasPrice and a gasLimit.

1000382428186365953.text:
3) The Truebit VM is fully deterministic.

• Resource limits (memory, native call stack limit) are fixed across the system.

• Floating point can be either canonicalized, emulated as integers (current impl), or disallowed in the system.

1000382342010163200.text:
2) The Truebit VM is based on WebAssembly, because:
• WASM is portable.
• WASM is designed to be sandboxed and secure.
• WASM is a compilation target for C, C++, Rust, ...
• WASM values map directly to 32/64 bit architectures.
• ...

992756760124456960.text: 11) What’s heartening: the system will be useful at various degrees of completion. E.g. the data layer, with no interpretation built in, can be used as a filesystem for Truebit tasks.

992756715794857986.text: 10) The implementation roadmap takes on battles one at a time: build 1) the random beacon, 2) the data availability solution, then 3) layer on state.

992756648300154880.text: 9) The architecture makes sense but there are details to figure out –– e.g. how to lessen load on the mainchain, how to use Proof of Custody within aggregate signatures, … with Ethereum grant funding available and sharding important work, it’s a good time to contribute.

992756394708389888.text: 8) The system will enable future upgradability of the network. Since rules are shard-specific: a new shard can have a different VM (e.g. WASM), a different inter-contract comms protocol (e.g. Primea), etc.

992756157797294081.text: 7) Cool to see ideas from other projects also inspiring the design – open-source in action – Dfinity’s random beacon, Truebit verification.

992756034895843329.text: 6) Other elegant constructions in the design – e.g. "cryptoeconomic aggregated signatures”: use a bitfield to summarize signatures and rely on the profit-motive of signers to challenge wrong data.

992755958714683392.text: 5) Another core idea: strike a balance between availability and security by escalating validation requirements from local to global via checkpoints – attestation, notarization, meta-notarization.

992755920286334976.text: 4) Core idea: use the random beacon to enlist subsets of the global validator pool for service across shards; regularly shuffle them to lower probability of collusion and bribery.

992755882617425920.text: 3) The current design has four layers: 1) a main chain contract, responsible for validator deposits and slashing conditions, 2) a random beacon chain, 3) consensus on data (transactions), 4) consensus on state.

992755835641192448.text: 2) So need to achieve consensus on subsets of transactions (the raw data) and state (the results of interpreting the data) in a way that balances security and availability.

992755776765792256.text: 1) Why we need sharding: if blockchain consensus relies on every node processing all transactions + storing all state, the network cannot scale beyond the capacity of a single node.
